title: R43779
content: The report provides an overview of the current Child Support Enforcement (CSE) system, including how international CSE cases are handled. It discusses the challenges faced by CSE workers in international cases due to lack of standards and communication methods. The 2007 Hague Convention on the International Recovery of Child Support is mentioned, along with the provisions in P.L. 113-183 related to enforcement of child support in international cases. The provisions in P.L. 113-183 aim to enforce child support in international cases by implementing the Hague Convention on International Recovery of Child Support. Supporters argue that noncustodial parents living abroad should still provide child support for their children in the United States. The U.S. had not ratified any treaty on child support previously due to jurisdictional differences. In most foreign countries, jurisdiction in child support cases is based on the habitual residence of the custodial parent. In the United States, child support enforcement relies on obtaining personal jurisdiction over the noncustodial parent. President Obama ratified the Hague Convention on International Recovery of Child Support in 2016 to strengthen the Child Support Enforcement (CSE) program enacted in 1975. The Child Support Enforcement (CSE) program aims to secure financial support for children from noncustodial parents and help families remain self-sufficient. It provides services such as parent location, paternity establishment, and collection of child support payments in all 50 states and three U.S. territories. The Child Support Enforcement (CSE) program operates in all 50 states, the District of Columbia, and three U.S. territories with federal matching funds. State programs are run at the county level and must meet federal requirements to receive funding. The Office of Child Support Enforcement (OCSE) administers the program at the federal level. State CSE programs have authority to use various methods to collect child support payments, including income withholding, intercepting tax refunds, liens against property, and reporting to credit bureaus. The 1996 welfare reform law required states to implement expedited procedures for securing assets to satisfy arrearages. The 1996 welfare reform law authorized various methods for collecting child support payments, including income withholding, intercepting tax refunds, and liens against property. It also required states to implement procedures to withhold licenses and passports of debtor parents who owe past-due support. Interstate child support enforcement is challenging due to jurisdictional issues between state and local governments. The federal CSE law mandates states to cooperate in interstate child support enforcement, but issues arise due to local court autonomy. P.L. 104-193 required states to adopt the Uniform Interstate Family Support Act (UIFSA) drafted by NCCUSL. UIFSA limits jurisdiction for establishing and modifying child support orders, resolves jurisdictional issues in multi-state cases, and determines which state's laws apply. The Uniform Interstate Family Support Act (UIFSA) is crucial for dealing with desertion and nonsupport by implementing uniform laws across all states. It ensures that only one state has jurisdiction over a child support case, allowing for effective pursuit of interstate cases. UIFSA establishes rules for establishing, enforcing, and modifying child support orders, following a "one-order system" where only one state's order governs an obligor's support obligation at any given time. UIFSA's provisions on continuing, exclusive jurisdiction limit duplicate and conflicting orders, reducing "forum shopping" by parents seeking to adjust child support payments. The Uniform Interstate Family Support Act (UIFSA) ensures one-state jurisdiction over child support cases, reducing duplicate orders and "forum shopping" by parents. P.L. 104-193 mandated the adoption of the 1996 version of UIFSA, which has been adopted nationwide. Additional amendments were approved in 2001 and 2008, with only 21 states and D.C. adopting the 2001 amendments. P.L. 113-183 required states to include NCCUSL amendments as of September 30, 2008, to receive federal CSE funding. The Convention on international child support cases aims to provide uniform, efficient, and cost-free procedures for U.S. citizens seeking child support in other countries. It allows countries to recognize and enforce each other's child support orders, similar to procedures in place for interstate cases in the United States. The Convention on international child support cases allows for efficient enforcement of child support orders between contracting countries through central authorities. These authorities will facilitate the transfer of documents and case information electronically for quick resolution. U.S. citizens can access cost-free services for child support enforcement in contracting countries, although some countries may assess minimal fees based on the child's income. The Federal Parent Locator Service (FPLS) assists in enforcing child support by identifying overpayments, fraud, and assessing benefits. It includes the National Directory of New Hires (NDNH), Federal Case Registry (FCR), Federal Offset Program (FOP), Federal Administrative Offset Program (FAOP), and Passport Denial Program (PDP). The Passport Denial Program (PDP) denies passports for child support debts over $2,500. The Multistate Financial Institution Data Match (MSFIDM) helps locate assets for child support. The FPLS accesses external sources like IRS, SSA, VA, DOD, NSA, and FBI for information. P.L. 104-193 established federal responsibility for international child support enforcement. P.L. 113-183 amends the Social Security Act to include requests for child support enforcement services from foreign treaty countries as if they were requests from states. It also exempts foreign treaty countries and individuals from providing applications or being assessed costs for these services. The Full Faith and Credit for Child Support Orders Act (FFCCSOA) was passed in 1994 to address disputes between parents living in different states regarding child support. It required all U.S. territories, states, and tribes to recognize and enforce child support orders issued by other jurisdictions.
